questions.question: A 10-year-old presents with recurrent episodes of facial swelling, particularly around her lips, along with a history of facial palsy. On examination, she also has a fissured tongue (lingua plicata) as shown below. Based on these clinical features, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive hearing loss in her right ear with a ringing sensation over the past 8 months. On examination, she has a unilateral sensorineural hearing loss on the right side. An MRI scan of the brain with gadolinium contrast reveals a well-circumscribed, enhancing mass about 4cm in size at the cerebellopontine angle. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Surgery Explanation: The scenario is of acoustic neuroma. Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with tinnitus and MRI with gadolinium contrast findings points to the diagnosis. Treatment of choice of acoustic neuroma is surgery Treatment Details Surgery Treatment of choice. The surgical approach depends on the tumor size. Radiotherapy Conventional radiotherapy by external beam is not suitable due to low CNS tolerance to radiation. X-knife or Gamma knife surgery: Form of stereotactic radiotherapy Focuses radiation on the tumor, minimizing the effect on surrounding normal tissue Arrests tumor growth and can reduce size Used for patients who refuse or are contraindicated for surgery, or with residual tumor after surgery. CyberKnife - An improved version Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, pages-132, 134 Current diagnosis and treatment in otolaryngology-head and neck surgery 2nd edition, page 767

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient was diagnosed with Acoustic neuroma. Which among the following cranial nerve is the earliest to be involved in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) V Explanation: Earliest cranial nerve to be involved is V , followed by VII, X, XI and others. Acoustic Neuroma: Clinical Features Age 40-60, both sexes equally affected Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus Imbalance, facial numbness, dysphagia in later stages Cranial Nerves Involved V: Earliest to be involved (Option A) , Reduced corneal sensitivity, facial numbness VII: Hypoaesthesia, delayed blink reflex, reduced lacrimation X, XI: Dysphagia, hoarseness May involve other cranial nerves as disease progress Investigations Pure tone audiometry: High-frequency sensorineural loss, roll-over or decay phenomenon seen. (Roll over associated with vestibular symptoms is called as Tulio phenomenon ) Speech audiometry: Poor discrimination MRI with gadolinium: Gold standard , ice-cream cone appearance seen. questions.question: Post-parotidectomy, a patient presented with complaints of sweating over the cheek region upon chewing food as shown. Which statement is inappropriate?

options.A: Abnormal innervation of greater auricular nerve with damaged facial nerve
options.B: Tympanic neurectomy is done for treating this
options.C: Starch iodide test is helpful in establishing a diagnosis
options.D: Interpositional flaps during surgery reduced the risk of this

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Abnormal innervation of greater auricular nerve with damaged facial nerve Cause: Faulty innervation of parasympathetic fibers of a uriculo-temporal nerve (Option A) supplying sweat fibers of face following Parotid surgery. Clinical features: gustatory sweating and flushing over angle of mandible Diagnosis: Starch Iodide test (Option C) Prevention: Use of Interpositional flaps like Sternocleidomastoid flap

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman presented with a 6-week history of swelling of both cheeks as shown, redness of eyes and cough. She reported having difficulty moving the right side of her face. On examination, Angiotensin-converting enzyme levels were elevated. Lymph node biopsy showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Heerfordt syndrome Explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a subacute variant of Sarcoidosis characterized by Uveo-Parotid fever and facial nerve palsy , known as Heerfordt syndrome . Heerfordt Syndrome: Subacute variant of Sarcoidosis, characterized by anterior uveitis, Parotitis and Facial nerve palsy . ACE (Angiotensin-converting enzyme) levels elevated. Biopsy shows non-caseating granulomas. Treatment: Systemic corticosteroids. Syndromes associated with Facial nerve palsy: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s Granulomatosis) (Option C) Autoimmune necrotizing vasculitis. Granulomas in respiratory tracts and kidneys. Facial nerve paralysis with Sensorineural hearing loss. Diagnosis: Elevated c-ANCA. Treatment: Cyclophosphamide + steroids. Lyme Disease (Option B) Cause: Borrelia burgdorferi , Vector: Hard tick . Flu-like symptoms, erythema migrans , bilateral facial palsy. Fig: Erythema migrans Diagnosis: Serologic testing. Treatment: Doxycycline or amoxicillin, if contra-indicated - Azithromycin. Ramsay Hunt Syndrome Peripheral facial nerve palsy with erythematous vesicular rash on ear or mouth. Melkersson–Rosenthal Syndrome (Option A) Recurrent alternating facial palsy, furrowed tongue , faciolabial edema. Moebius Syndrome Congenital agenesis of VI and VII cranial nerve nuclei. Seen with Misoprostol teratogenicity.

questions.question: The Blink Reflex test primarily evaluates the function of which two cranial nerves?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Cranial nerves V and VII Explanation: Electrodiagnostic tests are useful to differentiate between neurapraxia and degeneration of the nerve and also help to predict the prognosis and indicate time for surgical decompression of the nerve. Different electrodiagnostic tests are: Blink Reflex Test: Purpose : This test evaluates the integrity of both the trigeminal nerve (afferent pathway) and the facial nerve (efferent pathway). It involves stimulating the supraorbital nerve and recording the reflexive blink response in both eyes. Clinical Significance: An absent or delayed response, particularly the R2 component, can indicate damage to the facial nerve or brainstem. Electromyography (EMG): Purpose : Assesses the electrical activity of muscles at rest and during voluntary contraction. Helps to determine the extent of muscle denervation and reinnervation. In normal resting muscle, biphasic or triphasic potentials are seen every 30-50ms. In a denervated muscle, involuntary action potentials called fibrillation potentials appear after 14-21 days. They appear 6-12 weeks prior to clinical evidence of facial function and provide the earliest evidence of recovery Electroneurography (ENoG): Purpose: Measures the compound muscle action potential (CMAP) generated by facial muscles in response to electrical stimulation of the facial nerve. It is used to quantify the degree of facial nerve degeneration. ENoG is most useful between 4-21 days of onset of complete paralysis. Minimum Nerve Excitability Test: The nerve is stimulated at steadily increasing intensity till facial twitch is seen which is compared with the normal side. When the difference between the two sides exceeds 3.5m amp , the test is positive for degeneration. Degeneration of fibres cannot be detected earlier than 48-72 hours. Maximum Stimulation Test(MST): In this test the current level which gives maximum facial movement is determined and compared with the normal side. Reduced or absent response with maximum stimulation indicates degeneration and is followed by incomplete recovery. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, page 111&112. Blink reflex

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding transverse fractures of the temporal bone?

options.A: They are more common than longitudinal fractures.
options.B: Bleeding from the ear is common due to injury to the tegmen and tympanic membrane.
options.C: They commonly result in sensorineural hearing loss.
options.D: Facial paralysis occurs less frequently and usually has a delayed onset.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) They commonly result in sensorineural hearing loss. Explanation: Fractures of the temporal bone may be longitudinal, transverse or mixed. questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with a painful vesicular rash on his right ear, along with weakness on the same side of his face, making it difficult to close his eye. He also reports hearing loss and vertigo. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ramsay Hunt Syndrome Explanation: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome ( Herpes Zoster Oticus): Caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, it presents with facial nerve palsy, a painful vesicular rash around the external auditory canal and pinna. \ Fig: Ramsay Hunt Syndrome Ear There may be anaesthesia of the face, giddiness and hearing impairment due to the involvement of 5th and 7th nerves. questions.question: A 58-year-old woman presents with weakness in the lower right side of her face. She notes that she can still raise her eyebrows and wrinkle her forehead on both sides. Her emotional expressions seem normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.A: Lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Supranuclear facial nerve palsy Explanation: The scenario is of a kind of facial palsy in which the forehead and facial expressions are spared, which is supranuclear palsy of the facial nerve Supranuclear palsy of the facial nerve: The upper part of the facial nerve nucleus which innervates the forehead muscles receives fibers from both cerebral hemispheres. Forehead function is preserved in supranuclear lesions due to this bilateral innervation. questions.question: Choose the correct set of statements regarding the course of the facial nerve 1) The extracranial part of facial nerve lies lateral to retromandibular vein 2) Facial nerve exits the skull via stylomastoid foramen 3) Greater petrosal nerve is a branch of facial nerve after the formation of geniculate ganglion 4) The facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2,3,4 Explanation: Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons, a part of the brainstem, at the pontomedullary junction. Pathway: After its origin, the facial nerve enters the internal acoustic meatus along with the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). (Statement 4) It then travels through the facial canal within the temporal bone. Key Structures Along Its Course Geniculate Ganglion: Located within the facial canal, this is a sensory ganglion where the nerve fibers for taste (from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue) and some general sensory fibers synapse. Branches within the Facial Canal: Greater Petrosal Nerve: Arises from the geniculate ganglion, carrying parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland and nasal mucosa. (Statement 3) Chorda Tympani: This branch arises after the geniculate ganglion and carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands. Exit from the Skull Stylomastoid Foramen: The facial nerve exits the skull here, located between the styloid and mastoid processes of the temporal bone. (Statement 2) Extracranial part of facial nerve: Entry into Parotid Gland Main trunk enters on the posteromedial surface of the parotid gland. Division of Nerve Divides within the gland, behind and superficial to the retromandibular vein (Statement 1) and external carotid artery (ECA). Temporofacial vs. Cervicofacial Trunks Temporofacial trunk: Contains more axons but fewer fascicles. Cervicofacial trunk: Contains more fascicles but fewer axons. Formation of Parotid Plexus The trunks branch further to form the parotid plexus (pes anserinus) from which the terminal branches arise. Terminal Branches Temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical.

questions.question: A 50-year-old female known hypertensive presented with sudden onset weakness over the left half of her body. On examination, her face was deviated to one side associated with slurring of speech. The doctor asks the intern to perform a facial nerve examination. Which among the following statements is correct regarding the most likely intratemporal segment of the nerve involved?

options.B: Only segment of the facial nerve that lacks anastomosing cascades
options.C: Bill’s bar is related to this segment
options.D: Shortest and widest segment of facial nerve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) only segment of the facial nerve that lacks anastomosing cascades Explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute ischaemic stroke. Labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is most prone to ischaemia. Intratemporal Facial nerve: Extends from Internal acoustic meatus (IAM) to stylomastoid foramen. Further divided into, Meatal segment 8-10mm length, within IAM Bill’s bar is a bony landmark related to the Meatal segment of facial nerve (Option C) Labyrinthine segment 4mm length, from fundus of meatus to geniculate ganglion Shortest and narrowest segment (Option D) Most prone segment to compression (narrowest) and ischaemia due to lack of anastomosing arterial cascades. (Option B) Ends at 1st genu. Tympanic (horizontal) segment 11mm length, from geniculate ganglion to just above the pyramidal eminence. Most common site of dehiscence of temporal bone (facial canal) Lies above oval window and below lateral semicircular canal Mastoid (vertical) segment 13mm length,from the pyramid to the stylomastoid foramen Arises from 2nd genu. Most common segment to be injured in mastoid surgery Contains epineurial and perineurial sheaths (Option A): Proximal segments i.e Meatal, Labyrinthine and Horizontal segments lack Epineurial and Perineurial sheaths. Topodiagnostic tests of Facial nerve: Test Nerve Branch Assessment/Outcome Schirmer’s Test Greater (superficial) petrosal nerve A unilateral decrease in tear production ( >75% ) (Option B) or Bilateral reduction (less than 10 mm in both eyes after 5 minutes). Stapedial Reflex Nerve to stapedius muscle Reflex is either present or absent Electro- gustometry Chorda tympani The taste threshold is compared between the two sides to detect abnormalities Salivary Flow Testing Chorda tympani A 25% reduction in salivary flow is considered abnormal Reference: Diseases of ENT by Dhingra 8th edition, page- 108 Scott Brown's Otorhinolaryngology Vol-2 8th edition, page- 1383-1386

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient experiences sudden right-sided facial drooping and weakness in the left arm and leg following a stroke. The stroke is in the ventral part of the pons (basis pontis). Infranuclear fascicular fibers of cranial nerve VII (CN VII) ipsilaterally and the corticospinal tract contralaterally are affected. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Millard-Gubler Syndrome Explanation: Millard-Gubler Syndrome (MGS) Caused by a lesion in the ventral part of the pons (basis pontis) The lesion involves the infranuclear fascicular fibers of cranial nerve VII (CN VII) ipsilaterally and the corticospinal tract contralaterally. Results in: Ipsilateral peripheral facial paralysis. Contralateral hemiplegia. Cranial nerve VI (CN VI) involvement sometimes Foville syndrome: Caused by a lesion in pons Ipsilateral facial palsy Horizontal gaze palsy Contralateral hemiparesis Ipsilateral Horner syndrome Loss of hearing Facial pain or temperature sensation Contralateral loss of vibration, fine touch, and proprioception Wallenberg syndrome: Caused by a lesion in brainstem Difficulty swallowing Dizziness or vertigo Problems with balance and walking Involuntary eye movements (nystagmus) Loss of pain or temperature sensation on one side of the body Hoarseness Loss of taste Facial pain Weber syndrome: Caused by a lesion in midbrain Drooping eyelid Double vision Partial or complete weakness in the arm and leg on contralateral side of the body Pupils may be dilated and unresponsive if both upper and middle midbrain are affected Contralateral ataxia may be present There may be a parkinsonian type of rigidity Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532907/
